When I saw that Netflix added this, I shared no time to binge watch the entire series.Like many, I watched Avatar when it came out on TV. I always loved the show and would even beg to go watch it with my neighbor who had the box set of all the seasons. This show has always been an integral part of my childhood so like many things it has always made me feel nostalgic. So when I began rewatching it, I feared it would be like most nostalgic things you revisit, a letdown. So often we overblow our memories on something, like a TV show. But as I started watching, I realized how dead wrong I was.So I guess a quick plot setup would help for those who haven't seen it yet. Basically Avatar is set in a world where there are people who can control one of four elements: Water, earth, fire or air. Each element also corresponds to a nation (although not everyone in each nation can bend the element). However, 100 years before the shows timeline, the Fire nation sets out to take over the world and only the avatar (the one who can control all the elements) can stop them. The main character Aang is the avatar and was frozen in ice for 100 years before being found by Sokka and Katara. The show centers around those three and their quest to help Aang learn all the elements and defeat the fire nation.Okay. So this would be an excellent plot for a more adult show or movie yet they choose it for a kids show. This means that the show has quite a serious underlying plot that I believe anyone at any age would enjoy. That said, it is a kids show so there is a lot of somewhat childish humor but not so much that it dumbs down the show. In fact, there is plenty of scenes that made me laugh and overall it's a very enjoyable premise.So, let's get to what makes this show perfect. I see many reasons as to why this show is quite possibly the best one ever made. First off is the uniqueness of the show. It has a very engaging premise and one that really draws you in. Second is the design. The show is very beautiful and looks amazing. Third is the characters. The characters really make this show what it is and are truly amazing. Finally I'll talk about the underlying themes that make this show so much more than action scenes and humor for kids.The idea of bending elements is incredibly cool and I think most adults as well as children find that world to be one that is perfect to get lost in while watching this show. The idea of bending allows for so many cool twists to the show and always makes it interesting. The bending aspect is also an ever evolving one with subcategories coming up quite often like metal bending or blood bending. This allows the show to always stay fresh, even over it's fairly short runtime. Let's talk about runtime for a second. In a day with shows over 10 seasons and hundreds of episodes, it's quite refreshing to have a show that can be watched in 3 days. However, the short nature of it may seen to mean they have less time for storytelling. Perhaps this is true, but what Nickelodeon did in 3 seasons is remarkable. There was not a single episode or point on the show where you feel like the writers were struggling to make good content or where the show got bland. Having 3 seasons forces you to make a very sense and high quality story, something Avatar does perfectly. The whole show flows very well and is akin to very little else in that manner. How many shows do you know that don't run too long and run out of energy at the end? Going back to the unique premise, every episode adds some kind of bending type, or animal or new character. It's truly amazing to rewatch it and lose none of this thrill of the show. The writers also did a great job of really allowing you to feel like you understand the world and those in it. The premise and flow of this show are perfect.So this show is an anime. But it was made in America. This means you definitely get the best of both worlds. You get the beautiful Japanese art style with the landscape and characters. Although the show is starting to show it's age, it's still beautiful to look at. It has vibrant colors and at times changes the art style to spice things up. The facial expressions are sometimes over the top but overall, it's executed perfectly. Often times with anime the fight scenes are wayyy over the top, and yes the fight scenes here are dramatic but I think the shows strikes the perfect balance between too bland and too over the top. In fact, the fight scenes are really well done. The incorporation of the 4 elements is always a pleasure to see and never gets old. I guess art style is subjective, but in my humble opinion, I think the show is quite beautiful and even gets better over time.Now onto what makes this show perfect: the characters. Often in kids shows, the characters are pretty static and are just there for a good laugh. Take SpongeBob for example. All the characters there are the same and never grow. However, because avatar has a storyline (which is so rare in kids shows and is probably what allows this show to be perfect) the characters basically have to develop. Talking about ever character would take forever so let's just take one: Zuko. Zuko starts the show as basically the main enemy. He is deadset on capturing the avatar and is quite narrow-minded. His uncle iroh really cares about him and wants him to change but has trouble getting him to change. However, the show does a character arc that takes most of the series and is executed perfectly. Over time, Zuko begins to realize how futile his search is. He starts to realize that his father isn't worth it to fight for honor from. So as the series goes on, Iroh convinces Zuko that he needs to shape his own path. Over time, Zuko learns that his path is to help Aang and stop the fire nation. However, the writers of the show also wrote in specific episodes to show how Zuko develops and how he begins to realize that the fire nation is evil. The character arc with Zuko is amazing, incredible and worthy of infinite praise. He does a full 180 and it all makes sense and is written perfectly. This is just one character, almost all of the characters have some kind of arc and none of them are poorly written, bar one. This is my only problem with the show, and it's not particularly big. The big baddie that Aang has to fight at the end is Ozai, the fire Lord. Generally a good villan must be sympathetic or have a sad past or have a valid point in their struggles. The joker is a great example of a perfect villian. However, Ozai is bad because bad. He has no redeeming qualities and is just the big blob of evil. His intentions are purely for control of the world which is quite honestly not a bad MO for a villian, but his character is so superficial. But even then, Ozai's grandfather wanted to spread the prosperity of the fire nation with the world, hence why he started the war. But Ozai lost that original sentiment and is just out to rule the world. But overall, not bad for a kids show. Even the small characters almost all have two occurances in the show. The last season and the last few episodes tie in the almost all the characters in an Avengers Endgame type way. The characters are great and over the course of 3 seasons, you really feel connected to then and close to them. It's really amazing.Now to wrap up I'd like to touch on some nuanced themes that run throughout. One I see as very interesting is the clear ties it has to Communism. Okay Communism in a kids show? Nw way right? Hear me out. I think Ba Sing Se is a great example of this. First of all the whole city is surrounded by two walls, keeping the people in and enemies out. The government is clearly totalitarian but the king is just a puppet. The city is really controlled by an underground agency that keeps the "peace" at Bay. They use propaganda, censorship and brainwashing to push their agendas. Sound familiar. I would argue that Ba Sing Se is a perfect example of Communism and what it can lead to. However, the show takes a more brave new world approach insofar as the people are unaware that they are basically prisoners of the government and quite frankly, they don't care. It is a very subtle dystopian state. Now, this is all deep stuff, but it's really deep considering this is a kids show. This is just one example of many different messages and ideas that the show puts forward. It's crazy to think that a kids show as so many mature and complete ideas, yet it does and it makes the show amazing.So, Avatar. After almost 10 years, revisiting it has been a pleasure, to say the least. The show is literally better than I remembered and never failed it amaze me. I'm so glad that this show exists and it will always be close to my heart. So give it a watch, I guarantee that no matter how old you are, you won't be disappointed.

reviews.review_title: One of the great cartoons of the decade.
reviews.content: This series has a consistent storyline with a good plot and beginning, a middle, and an end. The attention to detail in the animation is amazing while still keeping a "cartoon feel". The best parts are the characters and the mixture of humor and drama, much like some of the best of TV like Star Trek, Monk, and Charmed. AT almost 50 years old I am happy to admit that I throughly enjoy the show after catching the pilot by accident on TV, I got my wife hooked on it as well. This is a show that is suited for children as well as adults and that is a rare thing. It does not focus on the "gross-out factor" or acts of random violence, and the story does not get lost in the fantastic. It also promotes some simple lessons about morality and life, which are good things to contain in a show directed mainly at young audience. I highly recommend watching this show.

reviews.review_title: A well-done cartoon that appeals to both children and adults.
reviews.content: I was flipping channels when I came across the Avatar the Last Airbender on Nick and it has turned out to be a really good show.The timing for the show's release couldn't have been better -- it came on the scene just as Cartoon Network stopped producing new episodes of Teen Titans. The artwork and animation are very well done and the show seems to have the right mix of comedy, action, violence, Asian culture,and mysticism. These elements, combined with well-developed characters and a decent storyline/plot make the show appeal to a wide range of age groups. It also seems that the show has blended the best of anime with American style animation -- think of the best elements of Teen Titans, Samurai Jack, and The Hakkenden (an anime show/movie from the early 90's)with touches of Disney-style animation elements. I also like the show for what is not in it -- namely the "trading card" duels that seem to plague many anime shows today. It also features voice actors like Mako who seem to enhance the quality of the show even further.My only fear concerning the future of the show is that they reduce the production budget or start cutting corners in the third season -- right now it is a high-quality show that I would recommend is worth a look from people of all ages.

Yes, it's all true - great story (for the most part), developed characters, lots of fun - it's all there, and it's highly addictive. Got me hooked right from the start. But it could've been so much more... Here the creators had a completely new world, to mold as they please, and all they did was to fill it with all the outdated oriental mysticism they could find. No imagination whatsoever, just borrowing every existing mambo-jumbo from the ancient Chinese, Japanese, and Hindu traditions. The same goes to the animals, cultures, architecture, clothing - just a random jumble of existing things, no novelty. Even the characters seem borrowed. For instance, Toph is just another version of He-Man (as crazy as it might seem), and Azula is clearly based on Mandy, even if you forget that they share the same voice. Another complaint is animation quality. Although it's certainly superb by Nick's usual standards, it comes up short when compared to modern animation series, and that includes the latest anime as well. In a series which relies so heavily on action scenes, I think they could've done a better job. And even though I'm generally a fan of anime, those silly facial gimmicks like large sweat drops and "angry lines" are my least favorite part, and I'd like to see it as little as possible. Avatar uses these gimmicks all too often, especially for a fake anime. As for the storyline, one of my problems is predictability. For example, I had no problem guessing the true identity of the Blue Spirit or the Painted Lady right from the start, or predicting that Ty Lee will betray Azula, and so on. And I'm generally very bad at things like that.Now for the good parts. Although the creators borrowed everything from oriental traditions, at least they enlisted some real experts on the subject. Kudos on that. Too bad they didn't add an astronomer to the bunch - some episodes cry for an expert in that field, especially the one with the solar eclipse. I also enjoyed seeing so many familiar names in the cast - apparently whatever money they saved on animation they used to hire some excellent actors. The second season was a bit too sad for my liking (though I loved the addition of Toph to the group), and I don't think that the plot justified all that tragedy, but the third season compensated for it with excellent, sophisticated, and funny (and not in a usual shallow way) episodes. As the ending approached, I was increasingly afraid that they might ruin the ending like they did for "Basquash", or, worse yet, end it with a cliffhanger like "Angel" or "Mortal Kombat", or even leave it unfinished like "Invader Zim". Fortunately, none of that had happened, and the ending was proper and (almost) decisive, albeit predictable and kind of flat, but tolerably so. I also felt that too many story lines were left hanging. I would've liked to see Toph's parents coming to their senses, Zuko returning his stolen ostrich-horse with apology, Azula in an asbestos mental institution, and a few other things. Normally, so many deficiencies wouldn't merit 8 out of 10, but I was so hooked to this series from the first episode to the last and then all over again, that I guess it deserves a fat bonus.

One thing in advance: I'm completely unfamiliar with any other Nickelodeon productions. This means I will solely judge the show on its own, with all the positive (no bias) and negative (no comparative values) implications thereof. With that out of the way, let me say that "Avatar: The Last Airbender" is an extraordinary piece of art. The animation, already decent from the get-go, seems to just get better and better as the story progresses. The characters are universally well-developed and likable (with Toph and Sokka being my personal favorites), the plot flows smoothly, and the combination of action and humor is splendid.Of course, there are also downsides. Not everyone will like the fact that Avatar is probably the biggest Ship Tease in existence; and some of the characters play the immaturity card a bit too often for my liking.All in all, however, Avatar's critical accolades are so jubilant for a reason: It's just that good. I'd recommend it for viewers of all ages (for the record, I'm in my early twenties) and many different genre preferences (Avatar has epic battles for action aficionados, hilarious humor for comedy fans, and several official {and plenty of plausible unofficial} pairings for the romantics.)Bottom Line: After carefully factoring in plot (8/10), voice acting (10/10), animation (9/10) and humor (10/10), I'll just ignore all those calculations and simply slap a big, fat 10/10 on the show for its sheer entertainment value.

reviews.review_title: Give it a shot, it's worth it!
reviews.content: Back in 2005 when the series launched and I was 7, I remember feeling so excited for every new episode each week. The animation, the story, the characters and the art of bending the elements - the avatarverse made wonders with my imagination. Today, in my mid-twenties, I can look back and understand why this series had such an impact on me. First of all, it's a war story that focuses more on it's consequences rather than on it's motives (which is rare), most of the cultural references are asian and the characters are amazingly diverse. This show really thinks out of the box and came at a time where diversity and inclusiveness weren't even that common on television, and still today Avatar is waaaay ahead than other contents in this department. During the three seasons we're taken on ride through amazing character arcs, complex politics, the weight of power, the importance of friendship and the toll responsibility and duty can have on someone. Some say it's a kid's show, I say it's a lesson on how to be human, kind and brave. It really doesn't disappoint, the storytelling is consistent, it isn't rushed and it doesn't leave you feeling cheated, it has a satisfying ending that manages not only to be true to the characters journeys but to also be unique, epic and bring closure to their arcs. If you go on this journey bare in mind that it has a bit of a slow start, but I assure you, by the time "The Storm" (ep 12) hits you'll be hooked! I loved growing up with Avatar in my childhood, and to be able to fully understand it's uniqueness and cleverness after all this years just made me appreciate this show even more. Really hope a lot of people get see this masterpiece of animation, it's worth it. ;)Ps: And remember: "there's no war in Ba Sing Se"

reviews.review_title: Could be one of the best animated series ever, but fails
reviews.content: The premise for Avatar is a great one, the universe is brilliant, the animation is very good, but that's all. It seems like the creators don't quite know how to handle all the power they've given to the characters. Fighting techniques and technology in action sequences are pretty boring. You can summon fire but you're still using knifes and medieval war machines? Serious lack of imagination there. This sort of top-of-the-head mundane approach to what could otherwise be an epic and innovative narrative, pretty much pervades the whole series on all levels and leaves it unfulfilled. The storytelling is rushed and primitive with no space for nuance and no respect for rhythm. This robs both the characters' depth and the worlds' seductiveness. Dialogues have no pauses, landscapes have no protagonism. This in my view is the biggest flaw of avatar and the one reason why it has no soul. The esoteric side of element bending and Shintoism was another great fountain of inspiration not allowed to gush forth. In the end Avatar is all action, and not very inventive at it either. But don't let me discourage you from watching it. It's still an entertaining an fun show as long as you can bear all its critical flaws and aren't frustrated for its infantile shallowness.

Any child of wit and intelligence will love this show. Like all good high fantasy, the story is seamless in nature, without a hint of falseness. The jokes are funny, the family relationships are true, and the creators obviously feel enormous affection for all their children. It's certainly the finest fantasy cartoon in television history. It never talks down, and no adult should ever be nervous about admitting that they are a fan. Themes of honour and trust motivate much of the narrative, and themes like that are particularly vital to young boys. Since the major characters evolve constantly, there is no telling where this story will end up.

reviews.review_title: One of the best animated series of our generation!
reviews.content: The show was originally intended for children, but I can say that it is very much enjoyed by teens and adults alike! Firstly, the storyline itself is something to marvel at. While incredibly fictional, it is also includes aspects that ring non-fiction. The Avatar world will go down as one of the most creatively constructed fantasy universes in history, alongside the greats like GOT, Harry Potter and Lord of the Rings. Secondly, the story tackles real life issues and historical catastrophes, like war, exile, genocide, as well as mondaine issues such as love and friendship. The sheer amount of life lessons and philosophies packed into both Avatar the Last Airbender and Legend of Korra is incredible, drawing heavy inspiration from Buddhism and Hinduism alike. Finally, the show despite being catered towards children becomes more enjoyable as you watch it when you're older. Indeed, having watched it as a child, I loved the show and the fantasy aspect, but rewatching over and over again as I've aged, I've come to appreciate the storyline, the craftsmanship and the life lessons, and I haven't gone a few episodes without crying each time. The series knows exactly how to grab hold of your emotions. It is truly a masterpiece!

reviews.review_title: The best I have seen in a long time

Like how Aang was raised by the nomadic monks of the air temple who discovered his heritage much sooner then he was supposed to due to the activity of the fire nation. his past is mostly shrouded in mystery though lately his past was revealed. Katara and Sakka are both practically orphans, as their mother was killed in a fire nation attack. I, like many others, really enjoy this show. The comedy is top notch and the originality is refreshing. It is a show that is appropriate to watch with your kids but entertaining for adults as well. While I enjoy the show as a hole, there are a few inconsistencies that exist that stop me from giving this show a perfect score. First, the bending.For the most part, the creators are very consistent and logical with the bending, i.e. there needs to be water to bend water, there needs to be earth to bend earth and so forth. Where they fall off is fire bending. Throughout most of the entire show, the character Katara has to keep a vial of water with her to bend water (as it would be ridiculous to pull water from the humidity in the air), yet most of the firebenders can bend fire with no fire around. Fire, unlike air, doesn't exist in its natural state everywhere and all around us, it has to be created via ignition, oxygen and a fuel source. But throughout almost the entire show, firebenders will just create fire from thin air. This creates a catch-22 in the logic of the show that ruins some of the credibility of writing.Also, lightning bending should have really nothing to do with fire bending, or at least it should really have more to do with air and water as the creation of lightning comes with the charging of air molecules creating added energy in the molecules, usually in the form of water. While lightning can create a fire, lightning is not caused by fire, thus fire and lightning should have nothing to do with each other.Lastly, and this is a purely personal bias, I think the machinations of Azula are too perfectly executed in most instances. Generally, the only times her plans fail are is if one of her underlings fail, not by any lack of foresight or fallability in Azula's character. Other characters imperfections are what make them so great in this show: Aang's love, Zuko's pride, Sakka's arrogance... These traits are what make the show great and Azula just lacks that and feels too perfect/fake. But again, this is just my humble opinion.

reviews.review_title: I'm not an anime fan but I gotta say this is worth watching.
reviews.content: I watched this series through a dvd when I was a kid but I didn't get all of it. Therefore I recently finished watching the whole series on Netflix all over again. It was one of the best series I've watched. Even though it was primarily made for kids, I enjoyed it a lot. The animation was great and the plot, I don't have words. Loved all the characters and their developments through out the series. Aang being insecure about his position in the world to defeating the fire lord, Katara being just a girl in the Southern water tribe to becoming one of the greatest water bending masters, Sokka as a boy who was left to protect the Southern water tribe to becoming the bravest soldier who end up planning the whole invasion, Toph being a stubborn overprotected rich girl to a person who puts other peoples feeling ahead of hers and protecting the whole world by her talents and discovering her metal bending abilities and Zuko being an arrogant prince who wants only the approval of his father by taking down the avatar becomes a selfless person who becomes the fire bending master to Aang at the end.And one of the main factors I like about the series is that how they presented the journey of the making of the avatar, all the fun, obstacles, lessons they had to face. It had an organized flow; balancing the main storyline with all the sub stories. Just after finishing ATLAB I watched the legend of the Korra and I'm certainly in need of another Avatar series. Hopefully there will be another.

This is one of the best shows on T.V - not the best animated one - the best period.First of all it has an interesting premise. 4 nations locked in a 100 year long war with each nation representing an element (fire, earth, water and air) and gifted people from within each nation having the ability to manipulate (bend) that element.The avatar however, has the ability to manipulate all 4 elements and is the only one who can end the war. The show is about Aang's (the avatar) journey to learn to bend the elements and end the war, all the while accompanied by his friends Katara and Sokka.The great thing about avatar is that it has interesting story lines, great character development, amazing action sequences and a lot of funny moments throughout the series.The show is supported by wonderful and original music and there is not a single boring episode in all 3 wonderful seasons! A show i highly recommend to anyone of any age, just give it a chance and you will be hooked!!

One of, if not the best-animated TV show, considering the target audience constraints they had that I've ever watched. The storytelling, the emotion, the magic... it feels like you sometimes enter another world. I have a small repertoire for animated shows, but I have watched shows such as Bojack Horseman, Gargoyles, Attack on Titan, Arcane, and Gravity Falls name a few. And I still put this show above all. I don't even understand what makes me like it so much. It may be that the writers absolutely nailed a show targeted at kids, but in a way where adults would still enjoy it. It comes from the fact that you inadvertently expect more from mature shows. And so a show targeted at kids done this well, well, it catches you off guard. Like, imagine comparing Bojack Horseman to Avatar. It's nearly impossible because they are targeted at different age groups. Would it be better if Avatar was made for a more mature audience (including substance abuse, mental illness, profanity, and more violence, to say the least)? Maybe. Maybe not. Would it be better if Bojack were created for younger kids, ages seven and up? Maybe. Maybe not. My point is this show did amazing, given the mature topics they couldn't discuss as other shows have. Are these mature topics necessary? For some shows, yes, if done well. Because I cannot imagine shows like BoJack Horseman and Attack on Titan if they were made for younger audiences.Avatar exceeded with a target audience that is easy to succeed in if that's the only audience they were targeting. But there were other audiences they were targeting. They targeted all ages while maintaining the beauty and magic a younger kid could enjoy. And that's what makes this show as great as it is. With all this, I rate this show as one of the best to do it, and although I can hardly say this to other shows I've watched, I would recommend this to anyone of all ages.

But you know what? This show never claimed to be a Japanese Anime, nor does it take place in Japan, it may have Japanese elements, but isn't an American show allowed to use some NON-American elements? At least they made them creative because they're not trying to copy tacky Japanese crap, they use all of Asia and then some, AND they did a lot of research to do it! My only complaint is that everyone's dressed to their countries colors.. don't you think that is a little too obvious? Well anyways, I give it a 10 out of 10.

What's good about Avatar: The Last Airbender? Pretty much everything is good. It seems like a flawless show that truly lives up to your expectations every episode. There are funny episodes, emotional episodes, serious episodes, and think of anything that you would consider good and the show has it all. Great characters and so much emotion are just a couple things that are so good about this program. Keep in mind as this show follows a direct storyline, there are minor spoilers but nothing major, only the revealing of few characters.The show take place long ago, where the four nations lived together in harmony. Then everything changed when the Fire Nation attacked. Only the Avatar, master of all four elements, could stop them. But when the world needed him most, he vanished. A hundred years passed and a waterbender and her brother discovered the new Avatar. And although his airbending skills are great, he still has a lot to learn before he's ready to save anyone. But the main character believes this new Avatar can save the world. Well, that is what the main character claims in the opening narration. The Avatar has been frozen for 100 years and the world has lived without him. The opening narration is bone chilling, but it appears every episode and eventually you just want to skip through it as it becomes very irritating after a long time.The show follows Katara, Aang, and Sokka and their travels across the world as they try and get Aang to learn the four elements that can stop the Fire Nation from taking over the world. However, there are villains who are constantly trying to stop or kill the group. There is Zuko, the prince who has been banished from the Fire Nation, and son of Ozai, the firelord. There is Azula, Zuko's sister, and her two other companions named Mai and Ty Lee, who are some of my favourites from the show. There is also Zuko's uncle, Iroh, the very wise man who is patient and tried to teach his beliefs to Zuko, even though he clearly is impatient with his uncle. There are also minor characters who appear every so often that interact with the group. During the second season, a young, blind girl named Toph joins the group and teaches Aang earthbending. She's such a fun character and is so tough, they are the most unlikely person to be a hero. There is Aang's flying Bison named Appa and Momo who is a lemur who has no major and significant role at all. But these two characters make the show so much funnier every time they are on screen.One of my favourite things about this show is that there are so many episodes that range from the emotions that are meant to be felt. There are scenes where the scenarios were intense, making it much more suspenseful. Other times there are just simply hilarious moments. In a scene in Season Three that the main character is hallucinating that he is watching his flying bison and a lemur speaking to him. Then they take it to the next level and then these two animals have a sword fight. I can't help but laugh at this for some reason.The characters are another thing that make the show what it is. There is Aang, the Avatar who is supposed to master the four elements, water, fire, earth, and air, however he must learn these to stop a ruthless firelord and multiple descendants of his that are trying to eliminate Aang who is the only person who can stop Ozai. Mai is my favourite though. She is such a lazy character and is always feeling so depressed and hates everything. Even her way of saying "I love you", happens to be "I don't hate you". She refuses to do anything she doesn't want to do but is still loyal to Azula. Ty Lee is also a fun character. She's a crazy circus freak who stuns people simply by punching them. Then there is Azula, the insane princess who is one of the best villains ever in television and cinema history. These three girls, who are only teenagers, have to be the perfect trio of villains in any text I have ever seen.Overall, this is one fantastic show. I can't think of anything to say that is negative about it. It's a nice family show but it so well developed it is hard to not like. Avatar: The Last Airbender isn't just a show, it's a masterpiece. The only disappointment is that the movie sucked. The one thing the film failed to establish was the relationships between the characters. The film was just simply so bland and boring. Meanwhile, the show takes as long as it takes to develop properly and become what we see when we watch it.

So, i wasn't suspecting a masterpiece when I first watched this, but in the end, it was one of the best series I've ever seen. What sticks out is of course the great art style, which is inspired by Asian and also American cartoon elements. The plot is well written but in the end it's just a bad-guys-destroy-the-world-plot, and is not great but solid. But the heart of this show are the characters, who are well written and believable at the same time: There's Aang, a boy who likes to play and make fun, but needs to grow up in the process of the story to save the world, but also Katara, who is grown up from the beginning, defined by her past.My favorite was probably Uncle Iroh, because he was the typical old, but when he wanted he could get pretty bad ass.There were only small things I didn't like, like the subplot with Appa, because Aang got like the little tearful kid, he never was introduced as. In the end there's only left to say, that only if you are a little bit interested in cartoon series, you should definitely go watch The Last Airbender, because of it's beautiful child- suitable art style, his great characters and the interesting plot-line about Zuko finding his fate, and realize how the fire-nation lied to him.

reviews.review_title: Great series and spiritual as well.

reviews.review_title: This show is for everyone, but...
reviews.content: I want to start by saying that this show is very great in bringing kind, natural atmosphere. All the characters are top-notch, especially Iroh, which is by my humble opinion the best elderly character ever written. Dialogue writing is EXTREMELY good, music fits very well into the scenes. This show is really something special, but there was also a bit of a disappointment for me.First problem is childish jokes. And jokes themselves are not really a problem since this is meant to be primarily show for children, but punchlines in them could make even old people laugh. The issue here is that there are too much of them, even in very serious moments like war-action they still somehow inserted plenty of puns, which ruined atmosphere sometimes.Second problem is the ending. SPOILERS AHEAD!!!They made the villain really stupid and awkwardly EVIL! He's so evil I almost started to laugh when he was present on the screen. There's almost no character development in Ozai, he's that cliched baddy that wants to destroy everything just because. But that's not all. I hate how they did every scene in the ending sequence, seriously. People standing ontop of a flying airships crushing into each other (I know this is fantasy world, but Sokka is not a magician!), this whole Aang vs Ozai fight was animated very bad, they just banged their powers while flying all around without any good music or thrill. Even Zuko vs Azula fight wasn't bringing any suspense while I was really hoping it would.As a result, I could stand children atmosphere to get magnificently good dialogues and characters, but there's gotta be a limit to it. Would've been 10/10 if they kept it a little bit more serious and ending wasnt such a mess. But even with its flaws I would recommend to watch it to anybody, Avatar: The last Airbender is truly special and sincere title that is worth seeing.

reviews.review_title: Anime or not, best show I've seen so far.
reviews.content: While other Animes try to shine with overly exagerated visuals, stupid amounts of power, this show is just beautifully balanced. The concept behind this world is so well thought through, that there is nothing alike out there. Not Naruto, not Death Note, not Dragonball. They all appear stupid compared to Avatar.The messages, whoch are thought by this show are deep and substantial. The characters are absolutely authentic and all shine with their own strengths and weaknesses. The cultural background and world-building is stunning! The capabilities of the characters are well balanced, yet absolutely creatively developed. The storytelling is heartbreaking, tense and for times really funny! Overall a must-watch, no matter the age!

reviews.review_title: Arguably the greatest show of all time
reviews.content: For my first review, I wanted to write about my favorite show/movie. I thought about which was my favorite, expecting an easy answer, but I found it impossible to decide. I spent my free time pondering this question until I eventually gave up and decided just to not write reviews. However one day, when browsing my YouTube subscriptions, I saw a Nostalgia Critic video on Avatar: The Last Airbender. Watching this video reminded me of how much I adored this show when it first aired, so I decided to re-watch it. Every episode was a joy to behold. Every character felt real, and I felt like I knew them. I was with them through the thick and the thin. This show managed to draw me in like nothing before. The animation was fantastic. The action was exhilarating. The music was beautiful, and the story was compelling. What more can I say? This show is fantastic regardless of the viewer's age. I will cherish it forever. 10/10: FlawlessP.S. The only show that can challenge this one will be the next one that I review. Here's a hint: Say my name.

reviews.review_title: One of the best Nick shows yet so far
reviews.content: This show is one of the best Nick ever produced. Nick Shows used to make really good shows, like Rocko's Modern Life and SpongeBob Squarepants, both are getting really old. Now, they're making really corny and horrid shows like My life as a teenage robot and Invader Zim (eugh!). I stopped watching those Cartoons as I found them old and corny. Some are just downright ugly!But when I accidentally switched the channel to Nick, about to show a program, which happens to be a brand new one, Avatar: The Last Airbender. I was so surprised to see that Nick is making a quasi-anime show (Anime but not quite anime, eg. Teen Titans, Martin Mystery). That episode I watched was freakin' awesome! About a 12-year old airbender named "Aang" trapped in ice for 112 something years, and he's the avatar. After that I got hooked to it. The next episodes were just as awesome. Though some were rather predictable (eg. "Jet"), it was still good. It is also good for grownups, as my grandpa also got hooked. Avatar is comedy together with action, heart and emotion, something that is rare. The only gripe about this show is the rather choppy and clunky animation. There are some instances that the program seems to have extremely brief pauses that can be seen to anyone with sharp eyes. Overall, it's one of the best quasi-anime shows I've watched. 9.5/10 Watch it, and you'll like it. Only people who don't dig deep enough (eg. look at Joshua Grave and Ginger 87's comments on page 3) WILL hate this show.

Why is it that everyone thinks that Nick isn't allowed to air some good shows. Cartoon Network and th Disney channel can't have all the good shows. I like the show because it talks about a 12 year old boy taking on a responsibility that no ordinary human could manage. He has the power to bend air and the power to learn how to bend earth, fire, and water. He is just a kid who should be doing normal preteen things but has the responsibility of having to save himself and the world from a comet.There are people who can bend the elements whether you believe or not it is up to you.

I was very surprised at how this show turned out. I thought that because it was a Nicktoon, it was going to be childish, like most of their other cartoons. But it had me hooked from the first episode. The animation is great, flowing smoothly from one scene to the next, and there are very few plot holes or continuity errors (wait... are they the same thing???). But what really got me was the detail and personality put into each character. Each main character has a history that comes into play at just the right moments, and is explained fully so I don't have to guess what happened (i.e., Zuko's scar. A very intriguing story behind that). So far, my favorite episode is The Blue Spirit. It had the best animation so far, and it was VERY exciting. The only thing that is a negitive with this series is the music. I find it is kinda repetitive and slightly annoying at times. But Overall, I give this show two thumbs up!

Avatar is a rare show in that it has humor, action, heart and soul. A great excercise in merging the best of east and west and creating something new and unique ... and finally a hero who is a hero as well as a kid. I think this fabulous new style is going to give Japan a run for their money ... way to go Nick! This has some eastern philosophic overtones ... but in the same vein as George Lucas and Star Wars, if you think the force and Yoda are OK then Aang and co are fine too IMHO. What is frustrating is that after "The Blue Spirit" they seem to have put the show on hiatus without any clue as to when new episodes will be aired. Does anyone know when new episodes will air? What's holding them up? Are the ratings low or something? I think this show deserves 9/10

reviews.review_title: Rewatched this at multiple times throughout my life
reviews.content: I absolutely adored this series when I first saw it air in 2005. I remember tuning in at random points, but I had seen all the episodes out of order. It wasn't until 2010, where I watched the whole series, that I could fully grasp the whole narrative.As a child, nothing ever made me question culture and moral principles as much as this show. Avatar spends a tremendous amount of time building its universe. Although American in origin, Avatar has many well-researched Japanese, Buddhist, Inuit, and Korean references. The main characters (Aang, Katara, and Sokka) are harmoniously crafted to provide unique perspectives throughout the story, evolving over the course of the entire series. Furthermore, the historical background and division of nations are exceptionally well put together. Each episode usually includes a short subplot with its own conflict that must be overcome by the end. Each episode ultimately ties in together to form an intricate web of realistic narrative. Since the premise is about a long-lasting war, there are several dark, real-world themes woven with philosophical and moral concepts. However, Avatar is also filled with witty and intelligent comic-relief and mesmerizing artistic imagination.In all aspects, Avatar: The Last Airbender, even after over a decade, is still a very enjoyable show to watch. Each time I have watched it, I still find new viewpoints and elements I did not notice previously. I believe this show still has yet to be beaten in both quality and creativity.

I'm sitting here in my room in quarantine watching this masterpiece and as an adult I'm sitting here crying because of all the emotion that's portrayed in every episode. It's just so real, this show is so heartfelt and raw. Practically every episode tackles loss, friendship, bravery and humility all tied in with some great humor. The show holds up so well. Has some great characters and villains,10/10 would recommend. Much better than Narutass and Attack on Mid.

reviews.review_title: Enthralling epic - for kids and everybody else!
reviews.content: I'll admit it: I was skeptical at first. I remember the previews before the show aired. I was 17 or so at the time, Avatar just didn't look appealing to me. I didn't start watching until the reruns came on while the second season was almost over, but oh man, I had missed out!The first season was entertaining; the action was, well, child-appropriate and the show had a refreshing sense of humor, but it did seem a little slow. The real savior of the first season is that the visuals are so beautiful!The beauty remains, and the character arcs and plots are top-notch in the second season and well into the third. Prince Zuko is one of the most fascinating, complicated characters in all of television, forget all of Nick TV. The original three characters continue to face seemingly impossible challenges and deal with like -get this- human beings! Toph adds a wonderful dynamic and steals the show on many occasions. The finale (and the episodes leading to it) is devastating and beautiful.The third season has been interrupted by the writer's strike and Nick being a jerk, but it's supposed to start up again soon, and I can't wait! If you haven't seen the show, I absolutely recommend watching it from the beginning, so be quick- get the DVDs and catch up!

reviews.review_title: One of the best shows on television.

Each episode, I believe, is another great installment. It keeps you interested and entirely entertained. And I'm a 16 year old girl. It's so nice to have an animated show to religiously watch, one reason being its superior directing. I find that this topic is rarely commented upon. After watching some of the battle sequences, or even a dialogue scene, you will know what I mean. Each fight is presented differently, in a different color, angle, view, you name it, highlighting exactly what needs to be emphasized for that particular scene. Avatar's characters, plots, action, humor, what more could you ask for? This show has it all. It's one of the best shows on television today.
This thing is a benchmark of how storytelling and animation should be done. 10/10. Amazing!!!

The filler its self isn't that bad, but at times I find myself wondering "if they need to master all of the elements in order to save the world before such and such a thing happens, then why are they wasting time doing..." If Nick were to up the frame rate for the more epic fight scenes I would probably give the series a 9, and if the characters could quit dawdling (I know, it's a kids show, but the characters seem intelligent enough to prioritize saving the world over some of the other things they are doing) then I would I've it a 10.

Avatar the Last Airbender is one of the finest animated shows to air on television. The characters are engaging, and believable. Constantly evolving, its ongoing plot has depth and intrigue that's simply not available on any other kid's program. The animation is beautiful, the backgrounds gorgeous. Avatar has often been confused for an anime cartoon, because of its high quality animation and Asian theme. It is, in fact, an American cartoon.When developing Avatar, the creators visited several Asian locations and did considerable research into the culture to make it feel authentic. Each nation (Earth Kingdom, Fire Nation, Air Nomads and Water Tribes) is based on a different Asain culture, and have different architecture and fashion. Also, each "bending" form is based on a different martial art form. The animators all took basic martial art classes in the different styles so they could draw them correctly.An amazing amount of thought and effort went into the creation of this program, and it shows its quality. Avatar is a superb cartoon, enjoyable for everyone.

reviews.review_title: Kid show? Maybe. Fantasy epic? Yes.
reviews.content: Pros:Avatar: The Last Airbender is a visual, audio, characterization, and world-building masterpiece, although it has minor flaws. The animations are fluid, the fight scenes are intense, and the facial animation is expressive. The score, voice acting and ambient sound effects are top-notch. Characters like Katara, Zuko, and Iroh will have you cry tears of joy and sadness. Although named after elements, the four nations seem like living, breathing cultures.Nitpicks:Although some plot details like Zuko and Iroh floating at sea for three weeks can be excused because the show is for kids, the main characters not thinking the Fire Nation would know about the Day of Black Sun stretches credulity.Also, (Disclosure: Proud Zutaran and Taanger) Kataang does not make sense since Katara is more mature than Aang and there was no relationship development besides him having a crush, kissing her when they were trapped in a cave, and stealing an inappropriate kiss before the invasion. Throughout the story, it seemed to be a brother/older sister relationship.Other than that and a few other minor gripes, Avatar is a solid candidate for best cartoon of all time.9.5/10 rounded up.

reviews.review_title: A must watch animated film series for those who wanted to watch action mixed with comedy, adventure, and thrill.
reviews.content:
AVATAR- The Last Air Bender (2005)
by Dave FiloniAn exciting American animated film directed by Dave Filoni with 3 seasons released in February 21, 2005 and was written by Michael Dante Dimartino and Bryan Koneitzko. This animated film was fixated to Aang, dubbed by Zach Tyler Eisen, who was the long lost and the last air bender. Aang was found in an iceberg by Katara and Sokka which was dubbed by Mae Whitman and Jack De Sena. Being an air bender, Aang has a flying bison named Appa and was dubbed by Dee Bradley Baker. Their stories will be intertwined and it is a must watch because you will weave each of them to fully comprehend the whole thing. I considered it as one of the films of modern cinemas because it touches on issues that are disturbing and timely as it should be considered.Just like any other films, Avatar- The Last Air Bender has a lot of twist and turn. Personally, I don't watch animated series, but after watching some of the chapters, I really wasn't expecting that this would be great and the plot was a real chef's kiss. Moreover, the film made use of basic
cinematography and it used different colors which also helped in the overall aesthetic.Furthermore, the characters, the editing, and the dubbing goes perfectly fine and for me, it was unprecedented. Everything blends well and came out exceptional. This film is a great reminder of the thing I aspire the most as of the moment and that is learning the circumstances from the past for me to be able to continue growing as an individual in the present.Many films of this genre are based on pure fiction. However, it is undeniable that ATLAB "Avatar- The Last Air Bender" reflects on realistic concerns, not just for yourself but for the people that surrounds you. One of the evident examples for this perspective was Prince Zuko. From the first few chapters, I saw how he tried to fit himself for the glory that was being forfeited if he will not be able to bring back the avatar. Given that the fire nation has conflicts with the other nations because they thought that they were superior, Prince Zuko faced his horrendous fate full of pressure.Historically, the terrible situation of Prince Zuko has something to do with what the fire nation did against the other three nations: Water Tribe, Earth Kingdom, and Air Nomads. Having the knowledge of wars, I know how hard it is leading while feeling defeated even if the war hasn't
started yet. In correlation to the film, Zuko knew that he should not underestimate Aang, the last air bender. In the film, the editing and the cinematography played the greatest role of giving the characters the justice of their roles. With the character of Zuko, this film added realistic ideas which the audience could relate.I love how Zuko's character evolved through the chapters. The editing was exceptional that I didn't notice it was Zuko who helped Aang escaped the fire nation until it was revealed in the succeeding scene.One of the things that captured me in the film was the transition of the characters' growth; how they react on things, how they decide, and how they approach life and its grueling events. The essence of character development and personal growth caught me. That you can be
a better version of you despite your past and that even if there are villains, being called "villains" doesn't mean they are evils because some just conformed for survival.There are also few things which I appreciated in the film. Due to the existing conflict of the fire nation against the other nations, I loved it when economic terms where substantiated and included in some scenes. This also helped in the development of the characters. Lastly, in the
political perspective, I find it fascinating when the film kind of reflect what political dynasty is since it involved families leading the tribes and the next generation shall continue what has been started by their ancestors. In the social light, it is also relevant when the film included how it's like to be alone and/orsurrounded by people who will support you through thick and thin, people who envy you for the things that you have, and people who can literally drag you down to hell.This is the first animated series I've watched in my entire life and I want more because of this film.As aforementioned, the production was excellent. Giving hints to the audience was unexpected and the character development was unbelievably amazing.In addition, the color scheme gave the scenes an extraordinary touch of excitement especially when it's a fight scene. Lighting was also good. However, there are scenes which has a shorter screentime and I can't fully understand what really happened until I review it. Overall, it
was very impressive for a first-time animated film audience like me.The best aspects of the film for me does not lies on the entirety of wars and tribulations, but the unpredictable scenarios which foster the growth of each character, protagonist or not.Regardless of those little issues I've encountered upon watching and taking notes of each chapter so that I will be reminded with how the story goes, I fell in love with the film not because of the amusement I had for the people behind it, but the storyline which moved me to certain realizations.This is one for the books! As a first-time animated film audience, I highly recommend Avatar- The Last Air Bender to those who wanted to watch action mixed with comedy, adventure, and thrill film. Again, I'm not kidding, THIS IS A MUST WATCH.

reviews.review_title: NOSTALGIA OR NOT. THE BEST ANIMATED SERIES EVER
reviews.content: From the incredible character development to the constant action and humor, this is just truly the best animated show ever, and in my opinion the best show ever, bar breaking bad. The Gaang are some of the best written characters in fiction who perfectly play off of each other. Dialogue is never dull as there is just an infinite amount of humor to be thrown around. While the first season is admittedly "weaker" than the other two, there is not a bad season in the show. Even the filler episodes seem to further characters and plot. And don't get me started on the season finales. Every season builds so flawlessly up to the finale and is resolved in such an amazing way. With the exception of two or three minor characters used for plot development, there is no character who isn't fully fledged out. Most notably, Zuko, who has imo the best arc in fiction (again, barring maybe Walter White) I can't say enough good things about this show. Everything down to the soundtrack is just *chefs kiss*. Watch this if you haven't, it is so worth it.

reviews.review_title: I haven't seen such a great show since DBZ!
reviews.content: I must confess: I waited 5 years to watch Avatar: The Last Airbender. Why? Well, to be honest, I really had no interest in it when it first came out. Why again? Ehh, I couldn't tell you. I don't know myself. Anyway, after finishing it, all I could think about was, "Why did I wait so long to watch this amazing show!?" Listen, if you are like I was, and haven't witnessed ATLA, then you are robbing yourself a great experience!The story is absolutely amazing! However, that isn't to say that this show is for everyone. What I mean is, you have to have an imagination, and it's best if you're a kid at heart. You can tell that parts of the script in virtually every episode is driven towards younger audiences. However, it's not like you'll be watching Power Rangers. There are many serious elements and moments in the story.Voice acting is a key element in an animated show, and can really rise it up to glory, or drown it in embarrassment. Not once did I find myself thinking, "You know, they really could have chosen a better voice actor." Each voice actor brought their character to life. The script for each character was very well written, and the voice actors did an amazing and convincing job making you fall in love with the characters!The only complaint I have is the length of the show, and I'm pretty sure I'm not the only one who thinks this. There are only three seasons to this magnificent work of art! This is so disappointing, because once you start watching, let alone finishing the show, you will be itching for more!So take the advice from someone who had virtually no interest in this and give it a shot. If you're ready for a fantastic show, you need to watch Avatar: The Last Airbender!Score: 10/10

The way each character interacts with one another you get captured by the shear thought of how the real world relates today. It has it all and to an extend broadens over the course of what every child imagined growing up from seedy, dishonorable pirates to esteemed royal patrons of a established family. first off, i've read some other reviews, and i read that it lacks creativity. It's true that you are not watching star wars, in terms of background innovation. "The elements thing has been used over and over" yea it has been used, so it is useless now? i find this argument lacking, the fact that a certain aspect has been used before doesn't mean it cannot be used again, otherwise we wouldn't be seen other things but globby beings which live in a lava world with no sun, and eat rocks.The series is a great show, in which characters are complex and everyone have their own problems and past, of course, it is not complex to a professional level, but for a cartoon, it manages a high variety of aspects which you wouldn't normally see in other shows. reviews.review_title: Great show- not like most Nickelodeon nonsense.
reviews.content: This show is probably Nickelodeon's only saving grace of the past decade. Ever since its debut in 2005, I've been loving it. The characters are real: unlike disgustingly flat SpongeBob SquarePants and company, Aang, Katara, and all their friends and foes through the series have souls behind the ink and paint. The concept of 'Good' and 'Evil' is taken through hell and back, bringing along characters like psychotic Princess Azula, vengeful Jet, and devious Long Feng. The show blends humor, horror, sadness, and romance together in a joyful hodgepodge of action that you won't want to miss. Give it a try! My one complaint about Avatar: The Last Airbender, though, is it's advertisements (i.e. on the Nicktoons Network, they used to make fart jokes about the program.) At the time of this review, there is a spin off miniseries in production, called "The Last Airbender: The Legend Of Korra".

Avatar The Last Airbender does a lot of things well. The show does such a wonderful job of building up its world and making it seem real. The characters are iconic and you can truly understand their motivations and goals. Zuko's transformation from a major antagonist to one of the protagonists is an excellent character arc. In general, the show is well written and paced.The show does have its faults, however. The first season is easily the worst and it contains some real clunker episodes ("The Great Divide"). It takes too long to really pick up, but when it does, it truly is wonderful. Some poor writing decisions also hold the series back. Although Aang not killing Ozai in the series finale does work from a thematic perspective, it's a poorly written deus ex machina involving concepts that were never previously established.Ultimately, Avatar The Last Airbender is a great cartoon series. Its influence on modern animation can still be seen today. Despite its flaws, it was very enjoyable to watch.

reviews.review_title: Very Nice but VERY VERY overrated
reviews.content: Avatar is a show about people who can bend various elements to their will.When the fire nation attacks the Dragon Warrior....sorry the Avatar must stop them.First the positives the animation and art are nice the characters are believable and dynamic the settings are creative and the story flows well and is predictable but not bad or tedious like say SAO or Fairy Tail.The negative is very simple and something that a lot of people avoid when praising it as a masterpiece which always bothers me.The clichés severely way the show down.I don't add clichés as a negative for most old shows from the 80s or 90s since they probably invented them but this show was made in the early 2000s it follows a lot of these clichés.Firstly the chosen one cliché the cliché I hate the most.This cliché is mostly caused when the author finds it difficult to set up events without making them seem contrived so they link it by a mystical prophecy or time travel.This makes the story very predictable and despite Avatar being very in the moment there's always that thought in the back of your head "Yeah he's not gonna die until after beating the main villain."Which is very unfortunate.Then is Aang having a hidden power inside him which he's afraid to use because he may hurt someone and doesn't want to be the hero.That doesn't sound at all like Peter Parkers Spiderman and Narutos Nine Tailed Fox thing.Fun Fact:When I was younger because of the similar artstyle I thought Aang was a bald Naruto.There are many other clichés but those are well executed enough that I'm not really annoyed by them.Should you watch this definitely just don't go in expecting Ghost in the Shell or Death Note but go in expecting a fun and heartwarming show.

He seems like an old, funny man who wants to spend his last days in peace, but is one of the strongest firebenders whose actions are crucial for the story. The Animation and Soundtrack are awesome. Especially in the last few episodes is the combination of fighting and background sound simply amazing. You see such a high quality very rarely in a cartoon/anime. There is just one small point of critique i have. Some episodes seem like fillers. They add no progression to the story or sometimes even collide with the behavior of characters they normally have. But this is just a small point. I was rarely that sad when a show ended. I really miss new episodes, especially since there is still much to tell. But that way Avatar ensures his very high quality, which other cartoons/Anime with > episodes don't have. Maybe there will be a cartoon about "the promise" and "the search" which have been published recently or will be published in the future. In the end, there is only one thing to say. Thanks for such an amazing show. Its a unique experience.10/10

Avatar: The Last Airbender is a so-called Pseudo-Anime (drawn in the style of anime, but produced outside of Japan). But don't let that put you off: this show is brilliant. It is set in a world ruled by four nations based on the four elements: Water, Earth, Fire and Air. Certain people in this world have the ability to "bend" these elements: to control them through willpower. This bending creates some very interesting fight scenes, and it's used for good and evil alike. However, there is one individual, the Avatar, who can master all four elements. The Avatar's task is to bring balance to the world and to keep harmony between the four nations. The show focuses on the current Avatar (An airbender named Aang) and his friends and their quest to bring balance to the world. This show really has it all. Action with well-choreographed battles and superb animation, romance, humor, serious bits, wisdom, incredible visuals (especially the scenery), and a universe that you can really get yourself into. In fact, this is a universe which endless shows could be made in, and it would still be interesting. The characters are lovable and relatable, and by the end you really feel as if you're part of their family and their adventure. Even the villains can be relatable at times, and there's great character development. The show runs over a course of 61 episodes, divided into 3 seasons or "Books". The story arcs perfectly, and instead of making the show longer to make fans happy, the show really ended at the right point and on a high note. Though it ran on Nick and is, in principle, a kids show, don't let that fool you; this show can be enjoyed by all ages. If you don't want to watch the show because of this you are deeply mistaken: this show appealed to me just as much at 6 years old, when I first watched it, as it does today at 16. Give it a chance, and you'll love it. But wait, there's more: if you've finished the show and, like me, just can't get enough, there is even more on offer. Three series of comics (a fourth is coming soon) follow the show that continue the plot and provide closure. Perhaps the best part of all is that there's an entire 4 season, 52 episode sequel called "The Legend Of Korra", that's just as good, if not better.If I had to sum it up in one word, i'd say : Perfect.

reviews.review_title: Some things should just be remembered as memories.
reviews.content:
I wanted to review this show after re watching shows from the past. Just as the Title says, this one has a bloated rating, and does not hold up. In the past I do recall preferring to watch Avatar, whenever it had aired on Nickelodeon. But it never quite stuck with me. I did also recall Upon viewing it I had become bored with its less that satisfactory elements.
To contrast some other cartoons i have revisited were; Codename KDN, Spongebob (seasons 1-3), Grim Adventures of Billy and Mandy, Ed, Edd, N Eddy. and all these were great cartoons when i was a child, and still feel entertaining to me as an adult. all with a charm that makes them what they are. but Avatar feels more bland like a Camp Lazlo. as I reiterate, something that I would tune in to, but never stuck with me.
Parts that didn't work was the pacing of the show. it just felt sluggish, dragged out and not going anywhere fast. this show, unlike the others i have listed was a story about a journey. going from point to point. they had to go somewhere and do something. it relies too much on way too campy childish jokes, and conflict where the threats and stakes didn't feel compelling enough to serve as good sub plot. i know that death doesn't make it a better show, but playing out that the fire nation commits genocide, and no one dies on the good side that makes any of the fights feel like the stakes are high or that Aang "Will save the world". I also wanted to note that the fights were nothing to write home about. the build up wasn't good, and the pay off neither better. which once again going from point to point on this journey feels slow.
Though I will always have fawned memories of watching in the past. there are way too many shows that were more special and set the bar higher in Animation, sound effects, story writing, and those shows deserve the watched, reminisced over, or viewed for the first time. it would be great if your in the age range of 7-12 that want a diet love, fight, good vs evil, story.
